[SYNTAX]: Overly complex, lengthy sentences may impede smooth readability (e.g., "It does not follow...").
[LEXICON]: Archaic phrasing ("fourpence-halfpenny edition," "Mæcenas of an evening") could slightly obscure clarity for modern readers.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from the dinner anecdote to the Colonial squatter story without explicit connective tissue.
[STRUCTURE]: Subordinate examples (e.g., _Sherlock Holmes_, _Mark Rutherford_) slightly delay the central argument but remain relevant.

[LEXICON]: Archaisms ("gay world", "sinewy English") and complex sentence structures may impede modern readability.
[SYNTAX]: Long, densely packed sentences (e.g., first sentence) require careful parsing.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from Sainte-Beuve quote to bookman’s personal preferences (e.g., Milton/Pickering editions).
[STRUCTURE]: Tangential details (Latin phrase, specific editions) slightly disrupt thematic flow.
